utterance: How's your sister, and that blessed baby?
speaker: Clifford Preston

utterance: How funny it seems. We have talked, thought, and dreamed of nothing but grad- uation all the spring, and it was over before we could draw our breath. I can't remember how I felt while reading my essay, and as for our clothes, that have cost us so much labor and ex- pense, I don't believe any one knew that Belle had on white kid slippers, or that Nan's hairpins were silver, and Emma's gloves had ten buttons.
speaker: Harry

utterance: We know you looked wonderfully pretty, and that is the main thing. But what are you going to do next?
speaker: Clifford Preston

utterance: You would think from the valedictory that we were all going to become something famous, but my career will be among the pots and kettles. I must be housekeeper, so that John and Bertha can marry.
speaker: Harry

utterance: Are you going to be tied down here too ?
speaker: Clifford Preston

utterance: I ought not to complain, after such an example as Bertha has set me. Poor patient dear! she has waited long enough for her happiness to deserve it.
speaker: Harry

utterance: Some one may want to carry you off some day. What will you do then ?
speaker: Clifford Preston

utterance: Not much danger of that, for the boys are all going out West.
speaker: Harry

utterance: Some of them may want you to go with them. That red-hot Democrat, forinstance.
speaker: Clifford Preston

utterance: I never accept second invitations, and I know he will ask Belle first.
speaker: Harry

utterance: I say, Harry, you would n't send a fellow off, if he should come, would you ?
speaker: Clifford Preston

utterance: You know what I mean. When I'm through college I 'm coming again, and you 'll promise to listen to me then, won't you, Harry ?
speaker: Clifford Preston
